head.title: Now You See 'Sicko,' Now You Don't

identified-content.classifier: Top/Features/Travel/Guides/Destinations/Central and South America/Panama/Panama Canal and Canal Zone
Waterways and Other Bodies of Water

hedline.hl1: Now You See 'Sicko,' Now You Don't
hedline.hl2: Now You See ‘Sicko,’ Now You Don’t

block.p: Michael Moore's documentary about health care in the United States, ''Sicko,'' appeared then disappeared from the Internet as the weekend gave way to Monday, The Associated Press reported. First at least two YouTube users posted a pirated 124-minute, 14-video-clip version of the $9 million film, which is not scheduled for nationwide release until June 29. Each of the clips attracted 500 to 600 viewers to the video-sharing Web site over the weekend before YouTube pulled the links, citing a copyright claim by Lionsgate, which is distributing ''Sicko'' with the Weinstein Company. Sarah Rothman, a Weinstein spokeswoman, said in a statement that it was ''responding aggressively to protect our film.'' Mr. Moore, whose previous films include ''Roger & Me'' and ''Fahrenheit 9/11,'' has supported the downloading of pirated films as long as the pirates do not profit.
Michael Moore’s documentary about health care in the United States, “Sicko,” appeared then disappeared from the Internet as the weekend gave way to Monday, The Associated Press reported.

Michael Moore's documentary about health care in the United States, ''Sicko,'' appeared then disappeared from the Internet as the weekend gave way to Monday, The Associated Press reported. First at least two YouTube users posted a pirated 124-minute, 14-video-clip version of the $9 million film, which is not scheduled for nationwide release until June 29. Each of the clips attracted 500 to 600 viewers to the video-sharing Web site over the weekend before YouTube pulled the links, citing a copyright claim by Lionsgate, which is distributing ''Sicko'' with the Weinstein Company. Sarah Rothman, a Weinstein spokeswoman, said in a statement that it was ''responding aggressively to protect our film.'' Mr. Moore, whose previous films include ''Roger & Me'' and ''Fahrenheit 9/11,'' has supported the downloading of pirated films as long as the pirates do not profit.
